awd_titl_txt: Measurements of sound velocity and density of core materials by combination of dynamic and static methods
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth's metallic core is the engine of the planet, providing the energy to generate its magnetic field and the driving force for plate tectonics. The properties the core control the function of the engine. It is fundamentally important to understanding the physical and chemical properties of the core in order to understand how our planet works. The density and velocity profiles of the core have been derived from seismic observations. Accurate measurements of density and velocity of core iron-alloys under simultaneous high pressure and temperature are required to derive meaningful composition models of the core. Dr. Yingwei Fei investigates the density and sound velocity of core materials over a wide pressure-temperature range by combining static and dynamic experimental methods. The results will be used to develop a comprehensive core composition model. The study will promote interdisciplinary research and significantly advance knowledge of the Earth's core and its influence on the dynamics processes of the planet. The projects will provide training in interdisciplinary research areas for graduate students and postdoctoral associates. The high-pressure techniques developed through the project will have general applications for synthesis of advanced materials, particularly super-hard materials.

The objective of the research is to obtain the best measurements of the density and sound velocity of core materials in the Fe-S-Si-O system by combination of static high-pressure compression and shockwave experiment. The proposed projects include (1) measurements of density and sound velocity of a Fe-9wt%O alloy and Fe-3wt%S-3wt%Si-3wt%O mixture by shock compression, and (2) additional measurements of density and sound velocity of an Fe-9wt%Si alloy by static and dynamic compressions. The proposal outlines a new approach to define the density and velocity of the end-member alloys whose compositions are close to the estimated core composition in a binary system. The data obtained in a suite of binary systems can be interpolated in a small range for a multi-element core composition that includes Fe, S, Si, and O. The interpolation will be further tested against new experimental measurements on a multi-element composition (Fe-3wt%S-3wt%Si-3wt%O), and ultimately narrow down the core composition range that is consistent with the geophysical observations.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The Earth's metallic core is the engine of the planet, providing the energy to generate its magnetic field and the driving force for plate tectonics. The properties of the core control the operation of the engine. It is fundamentally important to understanding the physical and chemical properties of the core in order to understand how our planet works. The objective of the project is to accurately measure the density and velocity of core iron-alloys under core conditions to derive meaningful composition models of the core by comparing with the seismic observations. The project provided the density and sound velocity of core materials over a wide pressure-temperature range by combining static and dynamic experimental methods. The experimental measurements are used to develop a comprehensive core composition model. Significantly, new techniques have been developed to directly obtain the shear wave velocity of core materials under core conditions to address one of the long-standing issues regarding the origin of the observed low shear wave velocity in the solid inner core. In addition, the project extends to exploring internal structure of super-Earths. Dynamic compression of mantle silicate has reached pressures over terapascals using the Z Pulsed Power Facility at Sandia National Laboratories, providing the first reference density profile of a silicate mantle in the super-Earths. The research has significantly advanced our knowledge of Earth's core and experimental techniques to explore the interiors of super-Earths.

Broader Impacts: The research opened new research directions in experimental geophysics through technical development and innovation. It promoted interdisciplinary research and significantly advanced knowledge of the Earth's core and super-Earth interior through combination of static and dynamic compression techniques. The high-pressure techniques developed through the project enhanced the capability of exploring materials properties under extreme conditions for the communities. The project brought two communities together, leading to a publication of an edited book on "Static and Dynamic High Pressure Mineral Physics" (Cambridge University Press). The project has also provided training for postdoctoral associates who have moved on to academic positions in research institutions and university. The results have been disseminated broadly through 12 peer reviewed publications in scientific journals, participations at several national and international conferences, and one edited book. 

 


Last Modified: 07/28/2022
Modified by: Yingwei Fei

    Yingwei Fei
    Public Domain
    Yingwei Fei
    Direct shock of mantle silicate to super-Earth pressures
